Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Track I, Phase II Noyce Scholarship project will prepare twenty New York State (NYS)-certified middle and high school science teachers for the rigors of teaching in both urban and rural high-need schools. Based on longitudinal research findings from a study of the first Noyce cohort, psychometric attributes of preservice teachers that are more likely to thrive in a rural or in an urban high needs school have been identified. Identification of these attributes will be used to place the Noyce II scholars in either an urban or rural setting, a process called "data-decided" placement. The project team will research the career trajectory effects the "data-decided" clinical teaching placements have on Noyce Scholars' careers and student learning. Extending the successes of the Noyce I award, the project team will also collaborate with the SUNY-Urban Teacher Education Center in providing internship experiences in high-need New York City schools. Moreover, graduates of the Noyce I program currently teaching in either high-need urban or rural areas have been called to serve as mentor-role models for the Noyce II Scholars. Additional science teaching curriculum supports are being provided by SUNY-Oneonta's Math for America Master STEM Teachers, the Catskill Area School Study Council, and the regional STEM Leadership Council. Longitudinal qualitative/quantitative research designed to understand how participation in the varied Noyce II program opportunities shape the career trajectories of the Noyce Scholars will be conducted. In particular, the project team is systematically analyzing reflective journal entries and semi-structured interviews of Noyce II program scholars before and immediately upon completion of early field experiences in the New York City Schools as a means for tailoring their later field work and student teaching experiences towards their individual career trajectory goals. Results of this qualitative/quantitative research will be disseminated in appropriate venues such as peer reviewed journals and conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The SUNY Oneonta Noyce Scholars Program recruited and prepared twenty-four undergraduate students majoring in either Biology, Chemistry, Earth Science or Physics for careers as science teachers in high-needs school districts. Recruitment efforts included outreach activities to high school seniors who applied to the college, informational seminars for freshman STEM majors and informational visits to many college classes taken by freshman STEM majors.

Preparation activities included seminars in pedagogy appropriate for middle and high school teachers, opportunities to practice STEM teaching in informal settings, and internships in high-needs school districts. Given the demand for qualified STEM teachers in high-needs rural schools as well as suburban and urban areas, all Noyce Scholars were provided opportunities to complete internships in multiple settings. Many internships were supervised by Noyce Scholars currently teaching in high-needs schools. Creating opportunities for college students to learn how to teach alongside Oneonta Noyce Scholar graduates now teaching in high-needs school districts was purposely planned to create a sense of confidence in the undergraduates and to ensure they are connected to a larger community of like-minded and newly licensed STEM teachers.  Additional teaching internship opportunities were created connecting Noyce Scholars with New York State Master Teachers. All New York State Master Teachers have highly successful teaching histories. Opportunities to learn alongside New York State Master Teachers provided a strong compliment to the experiences garnered under the tutelage of Noyce Scholar mentors. Overall, the professional development programming offered and the many opportunities to engage in internships in rural, suburban and urban high-needs school districts was planned to allow the Noyce Scholars to evaluate the type of school environment in which they prefer to begin their teaching career, while preparing them with knowledge and skills needed to succeed as early career teacher in high-needs school districts.

In addition to recruiting and preparing STEM majors for teaching careers in high-needs school districts, the project leadership team researched the effectiveness of the preparation activities on whether the Noyce Scholar undergraduates preferred to begin their career in a high-needs rural, suburban or urban district. Research data included focus group conversations, individual interviews and the analysis of reflective essays written about internship experiences. Findings of this research, presented to the Noyce community at each year’s Annual Summit Conference, described the positive outcomes of that accrue when Noyce Scholar graduates teaching in high-needs schools serve as hosts and mentors for Noyce Scholar undergraduates completing internship experiences, particularly in high-needs urban school districts. Additionally, data collected by the project leadership team supports a professional development model where Noyce Scholars learn content and pedagogy alongside New York State Master Teachers.

Overall, the research presented from this project demonstrates the importance of creating multiple and varied opportunities for Noyce Scholar undergraduate so that they may grow in terms of pedagogical and content knowledge, and grow in terms of confidence in their abilities to succeed as teachers in high-needs school districts.
